pros:
- Met some of my closest friends through working with them.
- Pretty good hourly pay.
- Could take on as much work as you wanted (up to 20 hours a week).
- Fun variety of work, some good experiences and transferable skills.
cons:
- Good luck getting promoted to Senior Ambassador if you don't suck up to senior staff.
- Lack of care for the welfare of any employees health or mental health (pre-existing health conditions will likely be ignored).
- Be careful who you talk to, the office staff were huge gossips who would spread rumours non-stop. 
- Senior ambassadors often very cocky and did not treat other ambassadors well.
- If you complain about anything (even reasonable things) you will not be picked to do shifts.
- Favouritism around handing out shifts, often went to the same people and some were left with no hours (and no income).
- When I started, you only had to work 2 open days a year but they changed it without changing our contracts and if you couldn't work one (!!) you had to provide a solid excuse.

pros: Working smong the student population, meeting some good people and a pleasent campus.
cons:
Worked as an employee of the university sports centre which was good at first.

But eventually a new manager was brought in who seemed to make every poor and shockingly odd choice he could at every oportunity. It was painfuly obvious he was tasked with removing all frontline long serving staff and aggresivly persued this goal causing many of us to leave. Some managers had no idea of how to do basic tasks but were more than happy to force these tasks upon others, people with zero workplace experience were progressed into senior managment positions ahead of good longtime staff, slander, bullying, favourtism and lying are things management are very guilty of and I shocked they have been aloud to get away with such things.

pros: Great pay for an entry level job, easy to pick up, give responsibility if you are suitable and ask for it.
cons: Hire some real interesting people who do not do their share, which is frustrating. Sometimes management can be a little overwhelmed with everything, and cause the atmosphere to be tense. Don't always recognise your hard work, so it is not so motivating.

review_title: Steer clear if you want to achieve anything
pros: Great campus, good pension compared to private sector
cons:
The 'command and control' management model needs to be binned if any kind of strategic success is to be delivered. 
Chronic under-investment in people means few teams have the required capabilities - there is no professional development, no performance reviews and no accountability which means a small clique of established middle management have free rein to do whatever they want. 
Lack of progress is masked by the noise and appearance of people being very busy  and the frightening lack of honesty and transparency prevents any kind of constructive dialog.

pros:
Short, fast-paced shifts, usually 4-5 hours depending on how busy the venue gets.
Set order for tasks, easy to pick up way of doing things, every member has a specific role during shift and these are rotated every shift.
Very easy to fit this job around studies as rotas are done on a weekly basis.
Easy to find cover on Facebook group.
Very good pay for how easy the job is.
cons: Enjoyment of shift largely comes down to which shift leaders and colleagues are working; the colleagues for the conversations during set-up/take-down and slow periods in the shift, shift leaders for their attitude towards staff.

pros: Some very clever people within the organisation especially the non professional services such as the academics and other teaching  related teams. The Principal has a great vision and turned around the estate providing great user experience around the campus.
cons: IT services a complete mess, bullying culture exists  and people who have built their career on passing blame on to others. The systems and other projects have been implemented poorly, any feedback is seen as contempt and engaging outside of IT is frowned upon.

pros: Great and beautiful surroundings, very leafy campus tho hard to get to in a middle of nowhere.
cons: Senior management has the lowest approval ratings in the staff survey in a history. No one talks about it, everyone just constantly complains about the organisation. IT systems are legacy, there are no processes in place. I am surprised this place still functions. Senior Management absolutely doesn't listen to the employees, they just do what they want. Keep building new buildings knowing that most of the teaching will be virtual in few years' time. Morale is very low, hence a huge staff turnover. Thinks twice before accepting a role here, you are about to be shocked what goes on here under the hood.

pros: Royal Holloway is a small and, still, friendly university environment with a focus on research AND student experience.  The main Surrey campus is very a very pleasant environment in which to work and access to central London facilities is a major bonus.  Many of the departments do research of international standing and have bright, motivated students.  Management are, on the whole approachable and the College’s ethos has, historically, been one of ‘light touch’ leadership. The foundation of both constituent colleges (Bedford College and Royal Holloway College) as institutions for women’s education provides a strong innovative ethos to much of the thinking at the grass roots level and to some of the senior management strategy.
cons: Recent changes in the senior management ranks have increased the level of managerialism.  Whilst this might, in itself, not have been a problem if this had been fully thought through and based on strong evidence the fact that much of the data used was highly contestable and that many of the initial announcements had to be reversed creates a sense of management ‘arm flexing’ rather than coherent, well thought through, strategic vision and direction.  The atmosphere does run the risk of an increased lack of collegiality and increased conflict between senior management and the rest of the staff.  The institution is, sometimes, too risk averse to respond to new opportunities in a timely fashion.  Finally the College suffers from being at a stage in its development which leaves it too big to retain the small college feel of the past and yet not big enough to reap the benefits of being a large HEI.

review_title: The best part time job available on campus
